questions.question: What is the empirical formula of compound 1?
What change in the crystal structure allows compound 1 to act as a colorimetric sensor for humidity?
questions.answer: The encapsulated organic molecules CH3CN and MeOH escape and water molecules from air come into the cavities, changing the color from bright yellow to deep red brown.

questions.question: Is the transition from compound 1 to compound 2 a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation?
What is the role of formaldehyde in the transition from compound 2 to compound 3?
questions.answer: Formaldehyde molecules replace some of the water molecules in compound 2, leading to a color change from red-brown to orange.

questions.question: Does the Cu(I)-MOF maintain its single-crystal nature throughout the sensing process for both humidity and formaldehyde?
What method was used to determine the crystal structures of compounds 1, 2, and 3?
How does the Cu(I)-MOF detect formaldehyde in the presence of water molecules?
questions.answer: The Cu(I)-MOF can detect formaldehyde even in the presence of water molecules by changing color in response to formaldehyde vapor concentrations.

questions.question: Is the guest-exchange process in the Cu(I)-MOF reversible?
What is the maximum emission wavelength shift observed when compound 1 transitions to compound 2?
questions.answer: The emission maximum is slightly red-shifted to 613 nm from 607 nm.

questions.question: What technique was used to monitor the sensing process of the Cu(I)-MOF for humidity?
Can the Cu(I)-MOF detect formaldehyde at a concentration of 0.0016 ppm?
What happens to the emission intensity of the Cu(I)-MOF when exposed to formaldehyde vapor?
questions.answer: The emission intensities of the HCHO-loaded samples are much enhanced with an increase in the amount of formaldehyde.

questions.question: Does the Cu(I)-MOF's sensitivity to formaldehyde depend on the presence of water molecules?
What structural feature of the Cu(I)-MOF is primarily responsible for its emission properties?
questions.answer: The Cu(I)-halide core structural feature in the ground state molecular structure is primarily responsible for its emission properties.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Cu(I)-MOF's ability to detect formaldehyde in real-world applications?
questions.answer: The Cu(I)-MOF's ability to detect formaldehyde at very low concentrations and in the presence of water makes it a potential candidate for a portable sensing device for formaldehyde pollutant in real-world scenarios.

questions.question: Is the color change from compound 2 to compound 3 due to a phase transition?
What analytical technique confirmed the presence of formaldehyde in compound 3?
Does the Cu(I)-MOF exhibit a color change in response to 0.016 ppm formaldehyde vapor?
What is the role of hydrogen bonding in the interaction between formaldehyde molecules and the Cu(I)-MOF framework?
questions.answer: The incursive formaldehyde molecules are hydrogen-bonded to the framework, which contributes to the structural rigidity and affects the emission properties.

questions.question: What is the observed effect on the Cu(I)-MOF's emission properties upon formaldehyde encapsulation?
questions.answer: Formaldehyde encapsulation leads to emission intensity enhancement, attributed to the structural rigidity imposed by the host-guest interactions.
